history.content:
It depends. Traditionally it isn't webcasted. However, to accommodate all the students that wanted to enroll last year, they decided to enroll past the lecture hall limit and therefore had to webcast. If the demand is so large relative to lecture hall size again, they will probably webcast. Also, there's a new professor teaching it, so I don't know their preference on webcasting. For more precise info, the head TA Valmik can give more accurate and up-to-date predictions.

About how needed it is, it depends on how the course is taught with the new professor, but I didn't watch a lot of the lectures last year. I found the discussion slides to be the most useful and clear resource, followed by the textbook (which I think they have a pdf of or you can find one online).

---------

Valmik here. Sastry's teaching it next semester, and I'm not sure what his thoughts on webcasting are. From what I've seen of his lecturing, he favors board work much more than Bajcsy and will likely go deeper into the math/derivations, so depending on your learning style this may be better. He's also got a lot of great stories about most of the material, since he either created it or collaborated with the people who did, so I recommend going just for that.

The book is free online but is very dense, so some students find it hard to use. Discussion slides will have more examples, so they'll likely be the most useful. If there's a lot of interest again and the department gives us money to open more lab sections, there's a good chance it'll be webcast.

Is this class usually webcasted? If not, how necessary is it to attend all lectures?
history.subject: EECS 106A Webcast
